TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in PERSON .
CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant married NORP In DATE NORP underwent infertility treatment so she could conceive a child with him .
CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant met PERSON In DATE he moved out of the flat he had lived in with NORP
CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON gave birth to their daughter , PERSON

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed a petition for divorce . At first he requested a no - fault divorce . In his petition the applicant referred to various marital misunderstandings and quarrels for which he blamed the respondent . He admitted that he had moved out of the matrimonial home , but did not mention his involvement with a new partner .

CARDINAL . At a hearing held on DATE the applicant refused to undergo the mediation process provided for by divorce law . NORP did not agree to a divorce , declared that she loved the applicant and asked the court to dismiss the divorce petition .
CARDINAL . Subsequently , the applicant requested a divorce on faultbased grounds .

CARDINAL . During the proceedings CARDINAL witnesses were heard . Most of them were of the opinion that the marriage seemed happy until DATE . Only the applicant ’s mother , his CARDINAL colleagues and his cousin recalled minor arguments between the spouses .
CARDINAL . During the final hearing on CARDINAL DATE the respondent reiterated her refusal to divorce .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused to grant the divorce to the applicant . The court held that he was the only person responsible for the breakdown of his marriage because he had failed to respect the obligation of fidelity . The court did not find it credible that problems had already begun within DATE of the marriage . It observed that until DATE the applicant had not wanted children . In DATE he had changed his mind . For that reason PERSON had undergone surgery , the operation having taken place in DATE .

CARDINAL . NORP The marital situation had subsequently changed when the applicant had met PERSON He had no longer wished to have a child with his wife . The court noted contradictions between the testimony given by the applicant , who had referred to the alleged serious problems in marital life prior to DATE on the one hand , and the decision to treat NORP ’s infertility in DATE on the other . The respondent had been shocked by the applicant ’s unfaithfulness and had been treated for depression since DATE .

CARDINAL . The court acknowledged that there had indeed been “ a complete and irretrievable marriage breakdown ” within the meaning of LAW . Reconciliation was unlikely as the applicant had consistently rejected all attempts made by NORP to reconcile their differences . Moreover , he had been in a relationship with PERSON for DATE and had a child with her .

CARDINAL . The court emphasised that under LAW of LAW , a divorce could not be granted if it had been requested by the party whose fault it was that the marriage had broken down , if the other party refused to consent and the refusal of the innocent party was not “ contrary to the reasonable principles of social coexistence ” ( zasady współżycia społecznego ) within the meaning of LAW .

CARDINAL . The court considered that NORP ’s refusal to divorce should be presumed to be compatible with those universally accepted principles . It referred to the case - law of ORG to the effect that a refusal of consent to a divorce was to be presumed to be compliant with those principles unless there were case - specific indications to the contrary . There was no indication that when refusing to give her consent NORP had acted out of hatred , was motivated by vengeance , or simply wanted to vex the applicant . The court emphasised that she had repeatedly stated during the proceedings that she was ready to reconcile with him despite the fact that he had a child with another woman .
CARDINAL . The court stressed that the duration of the applicant ’s new relationship could not by itself be considered to be a sufficient reason for granting the divorce .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed against the judgment . He argued , inter alia , that the court had erred in holding that a spouse ’s refusal to consent to a divorce could be disregarded only when it was of an abusive nature or was dictated by hostility towards the spouse seeking the divorce . The court should have examined the negative social consequences caused by continuing the formal existence of failed marriages . In his case , it had failed to do so .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal .
CARDINAL . The applicant did not request to be served with the written grounds for the appellate judgment . The grounds were therefore not prepared .
CARDINAL . The judgment was final , a cassation appeal against a divorce judgment not being available in law .
